title: Robert Miles: “Intro to AI Safety, Remastered”
oneLiner: Robert Miles — Intro to AI Safety, Remastered (YouTube)
whenToSuggest:
Candidate is curious but hasn’t tested AI safety at all
Candidate prefers video and wants a quick “do I care?” pass
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate already has strong familiarity and wants deeper field granularity
firstSmallStep: Watch the video and write 5 bullets: “what risks felt real / what felt off / what questions I have.”
nextStep: Watch the video and write 5 bullets: “what risks felt real / what felt off / what questions I have.”
internalNotes: Good default when you want the resource to “advocate better than you can.”

title: DeepMind: “AGI Safety Course” (playlist)
whenToSuggest:
Candidate likes structured learning and wants an intro under ~1 hour
Candidate is skeptical and prefers institutional framing
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate wants the EA community’s strategy framing (use 80k reading alt instead)
firstSmallStep: Watch the first chunk and note: “which track feels more like me: technical vs governance/policy?”
nextStep: Watch the first chunk and note: “which track feels more like me: technical vs governance/policy?”

title: 80,000 Hours: AI safety researcher career review
oneLiner: 80,000 Hours — AI safety researcher career review
whenToSuggest:
Candidate prefers reading
Candidate wants reality-checks on what the work looks like
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate is only looking for a quick interest test (use Robert Miles instead)
firstSmallStep: Skim sections: “what the work involves” + “who is a good fit” + write 3 bullets: “what matches me / what doesn’t.”
nextStep: Skim sections: “what the work involves” + “who is a good fit” + write 3 bullets: “what matches me / what doesn’t.”

title: AGI Safety Fundamentals (AISF)
whenToSuggest:
Candidate is interested and wants deeper understanding + community discussion
Candidate benefits from external structure/accountability
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate has no bandwidth for weekly participation (use Experiment A instead)
firstSmallStep: Read the curriculum/application page and see if week 1–2 feels exciting (not intimidating).
nextStep: Read the curriculum/application page and see if week 1–2 feels exciting (not intimidating).

title: BlueDot Impact: AI Safety / AI Governance courses
oneLiner: BlueDot Impact — AI courses (AI Safety / AI Governance tracks)
whenToSuggest:
Candidate wants structured learning + peers; not ready for a research fellowship yet
Candidate leans governance/policy OR wants a “less technical” entry option
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate is explicitly seeking a mentored project output now (use SPAR)
firstSmallStep: Pick one track (technical safety vs governance) and check cohort timing vs bandwidth.
nextStep: Pick one track (technical safety vs governance) and check cohort timing vs bandwidth.

title: SPAR (Supervised Program for Alignment Research)
oneLiner: SPAR — Supervised Program for Alignment Research
whenToSuggest:
Candidate wants to do something real (not just learn)
Candidate benefits from mentorship + defined projects
Candidate needs a push past impostor syndrome / “I’m not ready”
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate can’t realistically commit to the time window, even part-time
firstSmallStep: Browse the current/most recent projects; shortlist 2–3 you’d genuinely apply to and write 2 lines each (interest + feasibility).
nextStep: Browse the current/most recent projects; shortlist 2–3 you’d genuinely apply to and write 2 lines each (interest + feasibility).

title: MATS (Mentored AI Safety Training)
whenToSuggest:
Candidate is strongly research-leaning and wants a high-commitment path
Candidate is open to temporary relocation / intensive schedule
whenNotToSuggest:
Candidate is unsure about the field (start with A/B or SPAR)
Relocation is a non-starter

goodFitIf: Requires relocation (if a given cohort is in-person; keep this conservative)

firstSmallStep: Check the apply page and cohort details; sanity-check dates/relocation feasibility.
nextStep: Check the apply page and cohort details; sanity-check dates/relocation feasibility.

title: 80,000 Hours Job Board
whenToSuggest:
Candidate is ready to make roles concrete or is motivated by seeing real openings
Candidate wants a practical bridge from interest → action
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate is very early and gets overwhelmed by job posts (use Experiment A first)
firstSmallStep: Do the 10–25 min scan: collect 8–12 roles → label role-types → circle 3 roles + 2 repeating skill gaps.
nextStep: Do the 10–25 min scan: collect 8–12 roles → label role-types → circle 3 roles + 2 repeating skill gaps.

title: AISafety.com Jobs
whenToSuggest:
Candidate wants “AI safety only” without sifting broader EA jobs
Candidate wants to learn org landscape quickly
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate is not at job-search stage and would spiral into comparison
firstSmallStep: Same scan method: 8–12 roles → 3 interesting roles → 2 repeating skill gaps.
nextStep: Same scan method: 8–12 roles → 3 interesting roles → 2 repeating skill gaps.

title: EA Opportunities Board
whenToSuggest:
Candidate is earlier-stage and wants programs/projects not only jobs
Candidate is exploring multiple cause areas and wants a single “opportunities surface”
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate gets overwhelmed by breadth (use one concrete program card instead)
firstSmallStep: Search “AI safety” and save 3 opportunities that match your constraints/bandwidth.
nextStep: Search “AI safety” and save 3 opportunities that match your constraints/bandwidth.

title: ACE: “The impacts of AI on animal advocacy”
oneLiner: Animal Charity Evaluators — The impacts of AI on animal advocacy Animal Charity Evaluators+1
whenToSuggest:
Candidate wants a quick map and a balanced view (opportunities + failure modes)
Candidate is unsure whether “AI × animals” is a real thing vs hype
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate wants concrete examples first (use RP human–wildlife conflict piece)
firstSmallStep: ACE: “The impacts of AI on animal advocacy”
nextStep: ACE: “The impacts of AI on animal advocacy”

title: Rethink Priorities: AI for human–wildlife conflict mitigations
oneLiner: Rethink Priorities — AI for human–wildlife conflict mitigations Rethink Priorities
whenToSuggest:
Candidate wants examples and mechanisms (not just “AI will change everything”)
Candidate is pulled toward wild animals / conservation-adjacent routes
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate is primarily interested in farmed animals / food systems (use aquatic series)
firstSmallStep: Rethink Priorities: AI for human–wildlife conflict mitigations
nextStep: Rethink Priorities: AI for human–wildlife conflict mitigations

title: Faunalytics: “AI and Animal Advocacy” (survey-style)
oneLiner: Faunalytics — AI and Animal Advocacy Faunalytics
whenToSuggest:
Candidate wants a practical “what’s happening now in the field?”
Candidate is interested in tooling, workflows, comms, research support
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate wants deep technical + strategic analysis rather than usage patterns (use RP series)
firstSmallStep: Faunalytics: “AI and Animal Advocacy” (survey-style)
nextStep: Faunalytics: “AI and Animal Advocacy” (survey-style)

title: Rethink Priorities: “How AI is affecting farmed aquatic animals” (series)
oneLiner: Rethink Priorities — How AI is affecting farmed aquatic animals (series) Rethink Priorities+1
whenToSuggest:
Candidate likes research depth and wants to understand mechanisms and intervention hooks
Candidate is interested in farmed animals / food systems + technology
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate needs a structured cohort and peers rather than self-study (use fellowships)
firstSmallStep: Rethink Priorities: “How AI is affecting farmed aquatic animals” (series)
nextStep: Rethink Priorities: “How AI is affecting farmed aquatic animals” (series)

title: AI×Animals Fellowship (8-week, remote)
whenToSuggest:
Candidate wants structure, community, and a curated pathway
Candidate is exploring “future-facing animal welfare” and wants a coherent map
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate prefers independent exploration and gets stressed by cohort commitments
firstSmallStep: AI×Animals Fellowship (8-week, remote)
nextStep: AI×Animals Fellowship (8-week, remote)

title: Futurekind AI Fellowship (12-week)
oneLiner: Futurekind AI Fellowship (EA Opportunities / Electric Sheep) Effective Altruism+2Electric Sheep+2
whenToSuggest:
Candidate wants a longer, project-forward structured program
Candidate wants to build or research in this space with mentorship/community
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate can’t commit to 12 weeks; use AI×Animals (8 weeks) or Experiment A first
firstSmallStep: Futurekind AI Fellowship (12-week)
nextStep: Futurekind AI Fellowship (12-week)

title: Felidae Conservation Fund: Volunteer AI/ML specialist (camera imagery)
oneLiner: Felidae Conservation Fund — Volunteer AI/ML specialist (remote) Felidae Conservation Fund+1
whenToSuggest:
Candidate wants immediate hands-on contribution with real external users
Candidate has ML deployment/testing skills (or is close) and wants a concrete task
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate is very junior in ML and would be blocked by deployment requirements

nextStep: Felidae Conservation Fund: Volunteer AI/ML specialist (camera imagery)

oneLiner: Org-facing scoping note (AI × animals) — deliverable for an org/funder
whenToSuggest:
Candidate needs action to stay motivated / wants proof-of-fit quickly
Candidate can write clearly and wants a “bridge” from reading → doing impact
Candidate has impostor syndrome and benefits from a bounded contribution
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate won’t share outputs externally (then it risks becoming a personal learning project)
firstSmallStep: “Org-facing scoping note” using an RP AI-for-animals angle (externally useful)
nextStep: “Org-facing scoping note” using an RP AI-for-animals angle (externally useful)

whenNotToSuggest: Candidate can’t commit to any deadlines or deliverables

nextStep: Faunalytics volunteering (AI/tooling/research support lane)

title: 80,000 Hours: Factory farming problem profile
whenToSuggest:
Candidate wants a rigorous overview and “why this matters”
Candidate likes reading and structured argumentation
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate already knows the basics and wants concrete next steps (use C/D)

nextStep: Skim + write 5 bullets: “most compelling / most questionable / what I’d want to learn next.”

title: Jacy Reese: “Intro to effective animal advocacy” (YouTube)
oneLiner: Jacy Reese — Intro to effective animal advocacy (EAGxBerkeley talk)
whenToSuggest:
Candidate prefers video and wants a wide intro quickly
Candidate is motivated but needs a clearer strategy map
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate wants a structured longer exposure (use AAC course)
firstSmallStep: Watch and write: 3 role shapes you could imagine + 2 questions you’d ask someone in the field.
nextStep: Watch and write: 3 role shapes you could imagine + 2 questions you’d ask someone in the field.

oneLiner: 80,000 Hours — Wild animal welfare problem profile
whenToSuggest:
Candidate is more interested in wild animals than farmed animals

nextStep: Skim + note 3 intervention angles and whether each feels motivating or alienating.

whenToSuggest:
Candidate wants structured learning and a map of roles/orgs
Candidate is interested but still fuzzy on “where I fit”

nextStep: Read the course page + confirm it fits your bandwidth this month.

oneLiner: 80,000 Hours Podcast — Lewis Bollard on factory farm advocacy gains
whenToSuggest:

Candidate wants realism about advocacy and strategy
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate tends to over-consume content instead of acting (use C or D)

nextStep: Listen to the first ~30 minutes and extract 3 real-world constraints + 2 high-leverage roles.

title: Faunalytics volunteering
whenToSuggest:
Candidate wants a concrete project with real beneficiaries
Candidate likes research/analysis/writing/data/ops support
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate can’t commit to any deadlines at all right now

nextStep: Review volunteer options and draft a 3–5 sentence pitch: skills + a deliverable you can finish in 2–4 weeks.

title: Animal Advocacy Careers: Volunteer opportunities
oneLiner: Animal Advocacy Careers — Animal volunteer opportunities
whenToSuggest:
Candidate wants hands-on impact now but doesn’t know which orgs exist
Candidate needs a push from “theory” to “concrete help”
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate isn’t ready to commit to anything ongoing (start with A/D)
firstSmallStep: Pick 1 opportunity and send an application/message today (small + specific).
nextStep: Pick 1 opportunity and send an application/message today (small + specific).

title: Animal Advocacy Careers: Job board
whenToSuggest:
Candidate wants to explore roles/orgs without committing yet
Candidate is motivated by concrete job examples
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate gets overwhelmed browsing listings (use advising or course instead)
firstSmallStep: 10–25 min scan: collect 8–12 roles → label role types → circle 3 roles + 2 recurring skill gaps.
nextStep: 10–25 min scan: collect 8–12 roles → label role types → circle 3 roles + 2 recurring skill gaps.

title: 80,000 Hours: Job board
whenToSuggest:
Candidate wants broader EA options, or is considering adjacent roles supporting animals
Candidate wants a second job-board lens
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate is early and would spiral from job listings
firstSmallStep: Same scan method; then pick 1 role type to test via a conversation or volunteer task.
nextStep: Same scan method; then pick 1 role type to test via a conversation or volunteer task.

title: EA Opportunities board
whenToSuggest: Candidate wants programs/fellowships more than job listings
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate gets overwhelmed by broad lists (pick one specific program instead)
firstSmallStep: Search “animal welfare” and save 3 opportunities that match constraints/timeline.
nextStep: Search “animal welfare” and save 3 opportunities that match constraints/timeline.

title: Animal Advocacy Careers: Career advising
whenToSuggest:
Candidate is motivated but confused about fit/path
Candidate wants personal guidance/accountability
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate is progressing well self-directed and doesn’t want advising
firstSmallStep: Apply for an advising call and share 2–3 directions you’re considering.
nextStep: Apply for an advising call and share 2–3 directions you’re considering.

title: Animal Charity Evaluators: Giving recommendations
oneLiner: Animal Charity Evaluators — Recommended charities / funds
whenToSuggest:
Candidate can’t shift career soon but wants an “impact now” lever
Candidate wants giving alongside career exploration
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate is donation-averse or it feels like pressure (offer as an option)
firstSmallStep: Read the recommended list and choose a default giving option (even one-off).
nextStep: Read the recommended list and choose a default giving option (even one-off).

title: EA Funds: Animal Welfare Fund
whenToSuggest:
Candidate wants low-cognitive-load giving
Candidate wants giving as a complement to career work
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate wants direct control over where money goes (ACE may fit better)
firstSmallStep: Skim the fund page and decide on a one-time or recurring donation (if giving fits).
nextStep: Skim the fund page and decide on a one-time or recurring donation (if giving fits).

title: 80,000 Hours: Biorisk research, strategy, and policy (career review)
oneLiner: 80,000 Hours — Biorisk research, strategy, and policy (career review)
whenToSuggest:
Candidate wants a grounded overview + realism about paths (research/policy/strategy)
Candidate prefers reading/analysis to video
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate only wants a quick “field picture” and prefers video (use Jaime Yassif talk)
firstSmallStep: Skim “What does this path involve?” + “How to assess your fit?” and write 3 bullets: “fit signals / concerns / next question.”
nextStep: Skim “What does this path involve?” + “How to assess your fit?” and write 3 bullets: “fit signals / concerns / next question.”

title: Jaime Yassif: “Reducing global catastrophic biological risks” (YouTube)

nextStep: Watch and write 5 bullets: “what surprised me / what felt urgent / what role-types I can imagine.”

title: BlueDot Impact: Biosecurity course (~30h)

nextStep: Open the course page, skim curriculum, and sanity-check timing vs bandwidth.

title: 80,000 Hours: Biosecurity materials (topic archive / podcasts)

Candidate learns well via podcasts/interviews
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate tends to get lost in content consumption (use BlueDot or OBG instead)

nextStep: Pick one episode from the archive and listen to the first 20–30 minutes; note 3 “real-world bottlenecks” that stood out.

nextStep: Browse the projects page; pick 2 projects that seem feasible/interesting; write 2 lines each (why it matters + why you could contribute).

Candidate gets motivated by seeing real options
whenNotToSuggest:
Candidate is easily overwhelmed by listings (do A first)
Toe in the water step (≤60 min):
Use the tiny scanning method (8–12 roles → label → circle 3 roles + 2 skill gaps → 1 direction + 1 next step).
firstSmallStep: Probably Good job board (filtered to Climate Change)
nextStep: Probably Good job board (filtered to Climate Change)

title: Climatebase jobs
whenToSuggest:
Candidate wants a broad set of climate roles (tech/nonprofit/etc.)
Candidate is exploring “where could I fit?”
whenNotToSuggest:
Candidate wants more EA-filtered roles first (use 80k job board)
Toe in the water step (≤60 min):
Save 10 roles; label role-types and extract 2 recurring skill gaps.
firstSmallStep: Climatebase jobs
nextStep: Climatebase jobs

title: 80,000 Hours job board
whenToSuggest: Candidate wants high-signal roles and is open to adjacent paths
whenNotToSuggest:
Candidate wants climate-only breadth first (use Climatebase)
Toe in the water step (≤60 min):
Scan 8–12 roles → label → circle 3 roles + 2 repeating skill gaps → convert to 1 direction + 1 next step.
firstSmallStep: 80,000 Hours job board
nextStep: 80,000 Hours job board

title: 80,000 Hours: Health in poor countries (problem profile)
whenToSuggest:
Candidate wants an EA “map + why + how to help”
Candidate likes structured reading
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate wants video first (use GiveWell/GWWC explainer or Singer talk)
firstSmallStep: 80,000 Hours: Health in poor countries (problem profile)
nextStep: 80,000 Hours: Health in poor countries (problem profile)

title: GiveWell/GWWC YouTube: “GiveWell finds highly cost-effective charities — here’s how”
oneLiner: Giving What We Can YouTube — GiveWell explainer
whenToSuggest:
Candidate is new to evidence-based charity evaluation
Candidate prefers video
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate already “gets” the idea and wants action (use Giving cards or Project C)
firstSmallStep: GiveWell/GWWC YouTube: “GiveWell finds highly cost-effective charities — here’s how”
nextStep: GiveWell/GWWC YouTube: “GiveWell finds highly cost-effective charities — here’s how”

title: Peter Singer TED talk (via The Life You Can Save)
oneLiner: The Life You Can Save — Peter Singer TED talk
whenToSuggest:
Candidate is values-motivated and wants the “why care?” framing
Candidate is new to effective giving
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate wants concrete “what’s effective?” evidence details (use GiveWell)
firstSmallStep: Peter Singer TED talk (via The Life You Can Save)
nextStep: Peter Singer TED talk (via The Life You Can Save)

title: AIM: Entrepreneurship orientation video (<1h)
whenToSuggest:
Candidate is open to entrepreneurship (for-profit or nonprofit), even as a “maybe”
Candidate wants a low-cost way to test fit without committing to a program
Candidate is considering routes like “start a project,” “build a product,” or “launch an org”
whenNotToSuggest:
Candidate has clearly said they don’t want entrepreneurship
Candidate is currently overloaded and even a small new direction would feel stressful (then keep it as a later option)
firstSmallStep: AIM: Entrepreneurship orientation video (<1h)
nextStep: AIM: Entrepreneurship orientation video (<1h)
internalNotes: This works well as the “Experiment A” for entrepreneurship because it can advocate better than you can and gives the candidate a shared reference point before you explore heavier options (e.g., Charity Entrepreneurship).

title: GiveWell: Top Charities
whenToSuggest:
Candidate wants concrete “what works?”

whenNotToSuggest: Candidate feels pressured by giving (present as optional)

nextStep: GiveWell: Top Charities
